Answer: <<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: IStartAction action = iterator.next();
<<<explanation>>>: This line of code is causing the ConcurrentModificationException because it is trying to access the next element of the iterator while the collection is being modified by the removeNonApplicableActions() method. The removeNonApplicableActions() method is modifying the collection (by calling iterator.remove()) which is not allowed while iterating over the collection.

To fix this, you should not call iterator.remove() inside the while loop. Instead, you should call it after the if condition. Here is the corrected code:

```java
protected void removeNonApplicableActions() {
    Iterator<IStartAction> iterator = mActions.iterator();
    while (iterator.hasNext()) {
        IStartAction action = iterator.next();
        if (!action.isApplicable()) {
            iterator.remove();
        }
    }
}
```

This way, you are only removing elements from the collection while iterating over it, and not modifying it while you are iterating over it. This should prevent the ConcurrentModificationException.
